por.por_cntn:
This projectl suppoorted for the research of Paul Bourgade, on random matri- ces. These models are paradigms for physical phenomena like energy level repulsion, hierarchical self-assembly, disordered hyperuniformity, and for statistical complexity in high dimension.

Universality was proved in the past decade, for typical, spectral random matrix statistics. In a different direction, branching structures behind integrable random matrices and the Riemann zeta function have recently allowed to establish conjectures of Fyodorov and Keating about extreme, hierarchical statistics.

For universality of the spectrum, methods from probability (random walks, coupling) and mathematical physics (loop equations) have been decisive. 

More precisely, the PI and collaborators have recently made major progress concerning: (i) extreme value theory for correlated models such as random unitary matrices and ζ; (ii) the extension of gap universality to extreme spacings between eigenvalues of Wigner matrices; (iii) fluctuations for Coulomb gases in dimension two; (iv) universality of eigenvectors of Hermitian random matrices, and integrability of eigenvectors from the Ginibre ensemble. (v) universality and delocalization beyond mean field for random band matrices.

More importantly, the methods introduced for (i)-(iv) pave the way to complete a probabilistic understanding to longstanding questions, including the typical behavior of Riemann zeta function on the critical axis and Fisher-Hartwig asymptotics.
